summary: Paul Merson reignited his feud with Andros Townsend after Townsend was substituted into Tottenham's game against Burnley in the 83rd minute, which ended in a 0-0 draw. Merson criticized Townsend's brief appearance on Twitter. Previously, Merson had questioned Townsend's inclusion in the England team, but Townsend proved him wrong by scoring a stunning equalizer in England's 1-1 draw with Italy. Merson later admitted his mistake, expressing genuine pleasure for Townsend's success. However, the tension resurfaced when Merson made another critical comment after the Burnley match.

Chelsea have made an offer for 22-year-old FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto, as confirmed by FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane. If Muto moves to Chelsea, he will be loaned to Vitesse Arnhem, Chelsea's Dutch partner club, next season. The interest in Muto is unrelated to Chelsea's sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, has played 37 matches for FC Tokyo, scoring 16 goals, and has 11 caps for Japan with one goal. Although flattered by Chelsea's offer, Muto has not yet decided to join. He has been performing well, scoring three goals in four games this season, contributing to FC Tokyo's third place in the league.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in their first six months are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. Finnish researchers analyzed over 12,000 two-year-olds, noting that one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese, with those given antibiotics being particularly at risk. Repeated antibiotic use before age two increased this likelihood, with boys showing more pronounced weight gain. The study suggests antibiotics might alter gut bacteria, potentially increasing food availability for the body and appetite. Dr. Antti Saari highlighted the association between early antibiotic exposure and increased body mass, suggesting it might contribute to the childhood obesity epidemic. The study also raises concerns about the overuse of antibiotics, which could lead to resistance and the emergence of superbugs.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, an event witnessed by hundreds of tourists. The incident, which was captured on camera by a tourist named David Meadwell, occurred last week. The guard, dressed in full regalia, lost his footing, slid sideways, hit his bearskin hat on the sentry box, and dropped his rifle. Despite the fall, he quickly got up, though visibly embarrassed. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident. The Changing of the Guard is a popular daily event in summer and bi-daily in winter, attracting thousands of tourists.

The A&E networks, including Lifetime and History, are remaking the iconic miniseries "Roots" for a 2016 release. Originally aired in 1977 with over 100 million viewers, the new version will focus on Kunta Kinte, an African captured and enslaved in Virginia. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce. The remake aims to be original and contemporary, drawing more from Alex Haley's novel and consulting with historians for authenticity. It targets both fans of the original and a new generation, reflecting on recent historical and cultural changes like Obama's presidency and the Oscar win of "12 Years a Slave."

Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, claims that on his first day at Clarence House in January 1978, he was subjected to an attempted sexual assault by palace aides who tried to force him into an orgy. He was 27 at the time and left the job the same day after the incident left him in tears. His complaints were initially ignored, but after recent inquiries into historical child sex abuse, he contacted palace officials again last year. The matter was eventually passed to the police, who are now investigating. A retired royal aide denied involvement, claiming he was elsewhere at the time. The Royal Household has pledged to cooperate fully with the police investigation.

Jesse and Melissa Meek, an Oregon couple, announced their pregnancy through a rap video parodying the theme song from 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, which has over 1.7 million views on YouTube, features them rapping about their life and the surprise of conceiving quickly. They share a sonogram at the end, revealing their excitement. The video was made to inform distant loved ones and unexpectedly became very popular. They might make another video after learning the baby's gender. Jesse is a descendant of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film "Gone With the Wind" sold for $137,000 at an auction by Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills. The dress, originally slate blue-gray but now faded to light gray, was part of a collection of over 150 items from the film, owned by James Tumblin, a former Universal Studios hair and makeup department head. Tumblin saved the dress from being discarded in the 1960s for $20. Other notable auction items included a hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, Gable's suit for $55,000, and a bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland for $30,000. The film, based on Margaret Mitchell's novel, celebrated its 75th anniversary and featured Hattie McDaniel, who won the first Academy Award for an African-American actor.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after being dangled over the edge by his parents. The fall was approximately 10 to 12 feet, occurring around 3pm on a Saturday. The child was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived. He sustained minor injuries, including bumps, bruises, and a leg injury, but was not attacked by the cheetahs. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family, and the exhibit was closed following the incident. The cheetahs did not approach the child or his parents during the incident.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, originally used to enforce a 30mph speed limit, has been non-functional for over two years since all fixed speed cameras in the West Midlands were turned off in March 2013. This particular camera was found re-pointed at a house's front door. Birmingham City Council is aware of the situation and plans to send an engineer to assess and possibly remove the camera. The council is developing a pilot project with new digital technology for a limited number of sites, but this camera on Wellington Road will not be part of it. The house owners were not available for comment.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3, 2015, as part of the Jamaican team. Bolt expressed his readiness and enthusiasm for the event, highlighting Jamaica's successful relay tradition. Garth Gayle, JAAA General Secretary, is pleased with Bolt's participation, anticipating exciting performances. The full Jamaican team list will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves, both Barcelona football players, showed support for Barcelona's basketball team by attending El Clasico, where Barcelona narrowly defeated Real Madrid 85-80 in the Euro League. Despite this win, Real Madrid leads their division. Neymar recently captained Brazil to a 1-0 victory over Chile, enduring tough challenges. Before the international break, Barcelona won their football El Clasico, leading La Liga by four points. Neymar and his team are set to play Celta Vigo next in La Liga, aiming for a treble. Neymar's sister Rafaella also attended the basketball match.

Italy is dealing with a significant influx of migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe. Over a recent four-day period, 8,480 migrants were rescued by the Italian coast guard, with 20 distress calls received on one day alone. Save the Children reported a potential incident where 400 migrants might be missing after a boat carrying 550 capsized, though the Italian coast guard could not confirm this and found no evidence during a search operation. The number of migrant crossings and rescues has increased, with over 10,000 migrants arriving in Italy in the first three months of 2015, and 2,000 rescued in early April. Most migrants are from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. Since the year began, at least 480 migrants have died during the crossing, often due to bad weather and overcrowded boats, with some crews abandoning the vessels.

- **Alexis Sanchez's Choice**: Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool, and manager Arsene Wenger is pleased with this decision. Sanchez was courted by several elite clubs but decided to join Arsenal after the World Cup, influenced by Wenger's guidance.

- **Impact at Arsenal**: Sanchez has made a significant impact at Arsenal, scoring 19 goals in his first season.

- **Wenger's Perspective**: Wenger is unsure of Sanchez's exact reasons for choosing Arsenal but is happy with the outcome. He acknowledges Liverpool's interest might have been strategic during negotiations for Luis Suarez's transfer to Barcelona.

- **Sanchez's Qualities**: Wenger praises Sanchez for his quick adaptation, efficiency, work-rate, fighting spirit, and his ability to revitalize the team.

- **Upcoming Match**: The passage mentions an upcoming match against Liverpool, with no significant transfer speculation involving Raheem Sterling from Liverpool.

- **Liverpool's Performance**: Despite recent losses, Wenger acknowledges Brendan Rodgers' good management of Liverpool post-Suarez and during Sturridge's injury.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. At 35, he aims to cycle the furthest distance in 60 minutes, surpassing the current record of 52.491km set by Australian Rohan Dennis. The event will take place at Lee Valley VeloPark, with tickets available from April 19, priced at £49, £39, and £29. Wiggins, motivated by personal challenge and inspiring others, will also compete in the Tour de Yorkshire before focusing on this record attempt. The event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, with expectations of a full 6,000-strong crowd.

Serena Williams, the world No. 1 and twice French Open champion, struggled to beat Sara Errani in the Fed Cup, winning 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3, but found the match an 'eye-opener' for her claycourt readiness. Despite the win, the US lost 3-2 to Italy, with Williams and Alison Riske losing the doubles 6-0, 6-3, leading to relegation to World Group II. Williams admitted she wasn't as prepared for clay as she thought, needing to adjust her game. The US team, with many players in the top 100, aims to work harder to return to the World Group next year.

River Plate is interested in re-signing Radamel Falcao, who previously played for them before moving to Porto in 2009. The club's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed their desire for Falcao's return, stating that "the doors are open." Falcao, currently on loan at Manchester United from Monaco, has had a challenging season, scoring only four Premier League goals. However, he has recently performed well for Colombia, scoring three goals in two games. During his time at River Plate, Falcao scored 34 goals in 90 appearances.

Ella Henderson, a 19-year-old X Factor finalist and pop star, has become the face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson in various hairstyles against a vibrant city backdrop, promoting Batiste's dry shampoo. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency, and the campaign includes a TV advertisement with Henderson's song "Mirror Man." This endorsement is her first, as noted by Mark Hargreaves, CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, highlighting the natural synergy between Henderson and Batiste.

Aaron Siler, 26, was fatally shot by Officer Pablo Torres on March 14 in Kenosha, Wisconsin, after arming himself during a confrontation. Torres is on leave while the incident is investigated. A controversial billboard, funded by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, features Torres and thanks the community for support, causing outrage among Siler's family and friends who find it disrespectful. Siler was wanted on felony probation and parole warrants and was killed after a chase. Torres had previously shot another man, Terry Knight, 10 days earlier, which was deemed justified. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in a clash with militants near the Pakistan border in the town of Negur, Sistan-Baluchestan province. Three militants were also killed. The attack was claimed by Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian Sunni Muslim group from Balochistan, Pakistan, aiming to counter Iranian influence. Iranian officials have requested Pakistan to capture the surviving militants. Pakistan condemned the attack, is investigating, and has asked Iran for evidence, promising to apprehend the militants if they entered Pakistan post-attack.

The passage discusses a political inquiry in Japan regarding extraterrestrial UFOs. Defense Minister Gen Nakatani informed the Diet that Japan's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered UFOs from outer space, despite scrambling jets for unidentified flying objects, which often turn out to be birds or other non-alien objects. The question was posed by Antonio Inoki, a former wrestler and lawmaker known for his diverse career including wrestling, TV appearances, and political endeavors. Inoki, who has claimed to have seen a UFO, asked about Japan's defense measures against potential extraterrestrial threats, leading to Nakatani's clarification. This discussion echoes previous considerations by Japanese politicians on the legal implications of defending against space invasions.

Jin Pai, a 35-year-old passenger at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, China, was hospitalized after a toilet he was standing on to avoid touching the seat broke, causing him deep cuts on his leg and buttocks. He received numerous stitches in a Hefei hospital. Initially, he admitted to squatting but later told police he was sitting when the toilet collapsed. Authorities consider it an accident and advised that toilets are meant for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for sexually abusing a girl over four years and filming her and others with a hidden camera in a bathroom. The abuse started when the victim was nine and continued until she was 13. The investigation began when the now 15-year-old girl discovered the camera in March. Rebbie faces charges including aggravated indecent assault and invasion of privacy. Investigators found 41 videos, 34 of which showed victims showering. Rebbie admitted to filming multiple victims, including other juveniles, specifically targeting the 15-year-old. His preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1, with bail set at $500,000.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a unique photo series titled "Daughter and Salaryman," where fathers are captured leaping energetically next to their po-faced daughters. In these images, daughters look directly at the camera with a smile, while fathers, dressed in suits, perform dramatic jumps, sometimes with pained expressions due to their age. The series aims to showcase the fun side of typically serious fathers, portraying them as heroes full of excitement and hope. The photos have gained online interest for their unusual concept, though little is known about the project's background. The settings include various Japanese landmarks, and the poses vary from subtle jumps to more ambitious leaps, with some fathers adding playful gestures like peace signs.

The passage discusses the recent dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director, shifting focus to the upcoming county championship season. Kevin Pietersen, who was controversially dropped by Downton in 2014, is highlighted as he poses for a team photo with Surrey at the KIA Oval, showing a mix of deep thought and joviality. Pietersen's potential return to the England team is a focal point, especially after England's poor Ashes performance in Australia. Surrey is set to start their campaign against Glamorgan on April 19, with Pietersen aiming to re-enter the England Test team through his performances with Surrey. The passage also mentions various interactions during the photo session, including Pietersen joking with photographers and teammates.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian football club facing relegation, has sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender with 25 international caps, was initially fired on Wednesday but reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone. However, after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani, he was sacked again. Ceahlaul is currently 16th in the league, six points from safety. Ze Maria, who took over from Florin Marin in January, will be succeeded by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao, on loan from Monaco to Manchester United, has struggled to perform as he did before his knee injury, scoring only four goals. Manchester United is unlikely to make his transfer permanent due to his performance. Nabil Dirar, Falcao's former teammate, believes Falcao regrets leaving Monaco, where he would have played in the Champions League and might have been happier, despite not feeling well there.

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt robbed a dairy in Christchurch, New Zealand. Described as very tall, he stole the till with about $1500 after demanding cash from the owner's daughter. The incident occurred at 12:30pm on a Saturday at a dairy on Union St. The robber did not use any weapons, and police are seeking public assistance to identify him through Crimestoppers.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice. Initially arrested on March 19 for an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, she admitted to kissing him and allowing him to touch her breasts. She was released on bail and suspended from teaching. Subsequently, she was arrested again for allegedly having sex with another 15-year-old student on two consecutive nights in January in her car. This second arrest occurred after rumors of another relationship surfaced, leading to her being booked into jail again and released on a $50,000 bail. The school district took immediate action by placing her on administrative leave, preventing her from any student interaction or presence on school property.

A video showing a crocodile swimming in a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has gone viral, amassing over 500,000 views. The dog belonged to a local bike shop owner and was taken by the crocodile near a sanctuary 200 meters away. New Zealander Tim Weston, who witnessed the event, described how the crocodile held onto the dog for hours. The incident has sparked strong reactions on social media, with some expressing horror and disdain for crocodiles. Puerto Vallarta, known for its proximity to crocodile habitats, frequently sees these animals due to its location among mangroves and near a sanctuary.

Steve Bruce is confident he can keep Hull City in the Premier League despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton, which has left them just two points above the relegation zone. Hull has won only six of their games this season, with Bruce hoping eight or nine wins might be enough to avoid relegation. They have six crucial games left, including tough matches against top teams like Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players like Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Despite the challenges, Bruce remains positive about their survival chances. On the other side, Southampton's win moved them to fifth in the league, but their manager Ronald Koeman had to address a disciplinary issue when Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty instead of the designated taker, James Ward-Prowse.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was banned from teaching for at least two years after he allowed and made changes to students' SATs exam answers post-exam session, leading to the annulment of the entire school's SATs results for 2014. Despite claiming he intended to make answers more legible, a panel found his actions constituted unacceptable professional conduct. Guffick admitted to the allegations, showed remorse, but was still prohibited from teaching, with the possibility to appeal within 28 days.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper, married Swedish model Misse Beqiri in a beach wedding in Mauritius last year. Despite limited playing time at Manchester United, where he has only made 19 league appearances in five seasons and is now third-choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes, Lindegaard enjoys his personal life. He and Beqiri, who have been dating since 2012 and have a son together, often share their life on Instagram. Lindegaard has been linked with a move away from United, notably to FC Midtjylland, but no transfer was agreed upon.

The glowing blue letters from Yankee Stadium, owned by Reggie Jackson, failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction despite expectations of fetching $300,000 to $600,000. The only bid was $260,000 from a Sotheby's employee. These letters, installed in 1976 and removed in 2008, were 10 feet tall. Jackson, who bought them post-2008, hoped a new generation would enjoy them. Meanwhile, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500.

Brendan Rodgers, the Liverpool manager, addressed the recent off-field behavior of Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe, who were involved in incidents with nitrous oxide and shisha pipes. Despite these incidents, Rodgers chose not to discipline them but instead used the opportunity to remind them of their professional responsibilities. Sterling is set to lead Liverpool's line in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley, with Daniel Sturridge injured. Steven Gerrard is available after a suspension, but Rodgers has not confirmed if he will play. Rodgers emphasized the importance of learning from close calls in competitions, suggesting that such experiences are part of the journey to success.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, returned to London after the international break and shared a photo of himself relaxing with his dog, captioned "Home Sweet Home." He had recently performed well in Germany's 2-0 victory over Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier. Ozil is preparing for Arsenal's upcoming Premier League match against Liverpool. He missed Arsenal's last game due to illness but is expected to play against Liverpool. Despite rumors of him being in a Berlin nightclub, manager Arsene Wenger denied these claims. Since returning from injury, Ozil has contributed significantly with four assists and three goals since January, and he feels he is now well-adjusted to the demands of English football.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has confirmed that the club has no intention of replacing manager Luis Enrique, who took over last summer on a two-year deal. Bartomeu expressed satisfaction with Enrique's performance, noting that Barcelona is still in contention for three trophies as the season nears its end. Enrique's contract runs until 2016, and discussions about his future will be held later. Recently, Barcelona defeated Valencia 2-0 with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, has agreed to a new long-term contract with the club, extending his stay until 2020. His new deal is worth approximately £100,000 per week. Henderson, who joined from Sunderland in 2011 for £16million, has shown significant improvement under Brendan Rodgers, contributing 13 assists and 7 goals this season. He is likely to become Liverpool's captain after Steven Gerrard leaves for LA Galaxy. This contract follows extensions for teammates Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Meanwhile, talks with Raheem Sterling are postponed until the end of the season.

Filipe Luis, a Chelsea full back, has expressed his desire to remain with the club until his contract ends, despite interest from his former team, Atletico Madrid. He signed a three-year deal with Chelsea last July but has not secured the left back position. Luis is currently focused on Chelsea's Premier League campaign, with manager Jose Mourinho emphasizing the need for focus and winning every game. Luis recently played for Brazil in friendlies against France and Chile. Chelsea is preparing for a challenging end to the season with nine tough games ahead.

Nathan Hughes had his three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North overturned on appeal. Initially, Hughes was red-carded and banned for being 'reckless' when his knee hit North's head while scoring a try on March 27. Despite no intent, he faced sanctions but the ban was lifted due to widespread criticism. George North, who suffered his third concussion in two months, was advised to rest for a month. Hughes missed Wasps' Champions Cup loss to Toulon but is now eligible to play, though he won't feature in the next match against London Welsh. The appeal panel concluded the incident was accidental, not foul play.

A fiery sunset was observed in Washington due to smoke from wildfires in southeastern Siberia, started by farmers and exacerbated by strong winds on April 14. The smoke traveled across the Pacific, affecting Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia, causing intense red sunsets by filtering out shorter wavelength colors. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve, and the sunsets will return to normal.

Becky Schoenig from St. Louis, Missouri, had her new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. It was recovered by police after a tip from Mick Sexton, who recognized the car. When returned, the car had been modified with red spray-painted rims, red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook for "pimping out" her vehicle. However, she plans to have the car professionally cleaned due to the lingering smell of cigarettes and marijuana. Additionally, she is creating a smoothie named "Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor Mick Sexton.

Manchester City players stand to lose £500,000 each in bonuses if they do not qualify for the Champions League. The club uses incentivised contracts to comply with financial fairplay rules. After a loss to Manchester United, City is in fourth place, with their European qualification uncertain. They need to finish in the top four to avoid a play-off for the Champions League. The team has had a poor run, losing seven times since early 2015, including exits from the FA Cup and Champions League. Manager Manuel Pellegrini has acknowledged the team's poor performance, and their upcoming fixtures include matches against West Ham, Aston Villa, Tottenham, QPR, Swansea, and Southampton. Their failure to secure a top-four spot could impact their ability to attract top talents like Paul Pogba, who is also sought after by Manchester United.

In the 'mini-derby', Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 at Moss Lane, Altrincham. The match, which was free to enter and attended by nearly 1,000 fans, featured 13 English players, with 10 from Manchester. Callum Gribbin scored the winning goal with a free-kick. The game was tactically set up to mimic senior team play, with United using a formation with three at the back and wingbacks. Marcus Rashford missed two chances for United, while Marcus Wood nearly scored for City. The result keeps United two points behind league leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City has lost both their playoff matches. The match showcased young talents who might deserve first-team opportunities in the future.

Joe Hart, an England goalkeeper, praised Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' after Buffon earned his 147th cap for Italy. This occurred during a 1-1 draw between England and Italy, where Hart also celebrated his 50th cap for England. Hart, who is 10 years younger than Buffon, expressed admiration for Buffon's career longevity and performance at 37, viewing him as an inspiration. Hart aims to continue his international career, expressing a desire to keep playing well for both club and country.

Chipotle has entered the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to deliver food in 67 cities. This service includes a 9% service charge and delivery fees starting at $5. Previously, Chipotle had declined offers from other delivery services but has now chosen Postmates, which uses independent contractors similar to Uber. Recently, presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton were seen at Chipotle locations. Other chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring delivery services.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, have publicly urged the Justice Department to remove the death penalty from consideration for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted on all 30 charges related to the bombings. In a Boston Globe opinion piece, Bill and Denise Richard detailed the profound impact of their son's death and their daughter's severe injuries, expressing their desire for closure by having Tsarnaev serve life in prison without parole instead of facing the death penalty. They argue this would prevent prolonged legal appeals and further pain for their family. The sentencing phase for Tsarnaev began shortly after the 2014 Boston Marathon, expected to last four weeks.

A mystery billionaire has transformed a Boeing 747 into a luxurious private home, costing £400million. The jet, customized over three years, includes multiple bedrooms, lounges, a dining room with an adjacent kitchen, and an 'aeroloft' with eight beds. It features a master bedroom, conference room, and various lounges designed to resemble luxury hotel rooms, providing a hotel-like ambiance far surpassing commercial first-class experiences. The plane can accommodate dozens of guests, offering spaces for relaxation, work, and entertainment.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket with an uncrewed Dragon spacecraft from Cape Canaveral, Florida, to the International Space Station. The rocket's first stage attempted to land on a floating barge but failed, tipping over upon landing. This was SpaceX's second attempt at such a landing, following a previous failure. The goal is to reuse rockets to significantly reduce space travel costs. The Dragon will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including an espresso maker, to the ISS. After about five weeks, the Dragon will return with over 3,000 pounds of materials, splashing down in the Pacific Ocean. This was SpaceX's sixth mission to the ISS, with the launch delayed from Monday due to weather.

Priscilla Presley will witness the first wedding at the newly opened Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas, located at the Westgate Hotel, where Elvis performed over 830 shows. The wedding, set for April 23, is part of a contest by NBC's Today show for an Elvis-obsessed couple, offering them a free wedding, reception, two-night hotel stay, airfares, and tickets to the Elvis Experience show. Priscilla has ensured the chapel is first-class and serious, with no Elvis impersonators allowed. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis, and couples must submit videos or photos explaining why they deserve to win to participate in the contest.

Jordan Henderson believes Liverpool can catch Manchester City in the Premier League race, especially after their 2-0 win over Newcastle United, where both Henderson and Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season. Liverpool are four points behind Manchester City, who have recently shown signs of faltering. In the match, Raheem Sterling scored first, followed by Joe Allen's first Anfield goal, which came from a defensive error by Newcastle. Despite a potential penalty incident involving Dejan Lovren, Liverpool secured the win, which Henderson sees as crucial in their push for a Champions League spot.

Roma ended a four-month winless streak at home by defeating Napoli 1-0 in Serie A, with Miralem Pjanic scoring in the 25th minute from a counter-attack. Goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis was crucial, making several saves in the second half. This victory moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of Lazio, while Napoli extended their winless streak to five matches, remaining in fifth place. Security was heightened due to past incidents, with restrictions on ticket sales and a significant police presence, but no issues were reported. Roma played without key players Francesco Totti and Gervinho.

Doncaster Rovers had a lackluster season, remaining mid-table in League One. Their match against Fleetwood Town, who had lost hope for playoffs, ended in a 0-0 draw at the Keepmoat Stadium. The match was uneventful, leading to a very brief 27-second highlight video on the club's YouTube channel, featuring only 14 seconds of actual gameplay including the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux has a unique relationship with his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid fish first bred in Taiwan in 1986. Unlike typical marine pets, this fish interacts with Giroux through touch, allowing him to stroke and massage it. Initially, the fish would swim away but soon returned for more interaction, showing signs of enjoyment by staying still during the massage. Giroux removed two other fish from the tank due to bullying, which led to the cichlid becoming more sociable. He feeds it by hand and spends at least 15 minutes daily playing with it, noting that the fish becomes frustrated if not interacted with regularly. The video captures the fish following Giroux's hand to the water's surface when he removes it, indicating a bond between them.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery character in the England cricket team, returned to play at Kensington Oval, where he previously broke his wrist punching a locker. His aggression needs careful management, as demonstrated by his positive response after a clash with Marlon Samuels, guided by coach Peter Moores. Stokes' natural exuberance is valued, but must be controlled to ensure it contributes to runs and wickets. Despite a minor back issue, England aims to include Stokes frequently to help him reach his potential. The team also considers playing both Stokes and Chris Jordan, preferring them over a second spinner like Adil Rashid, to foster their growth in international cricket.

The Euro 2016 qualifier match between Wales and Belgium, set for June 12 at Cardiff City Stadium, has sold out with 33,000 tickets. Both teams are leading Group B with 11 points each, with Belgium ahead due to a better goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 win over Israel has boosted expectations for qualification. High demand led to the sell-out, and despite speculation, the match will be at Cardiff City Stadium, not the larger Millennium Stadium, due to UEFA rules and player preference.

John Peacock has selected the England Under-17 squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where they are defending champions after defeating Holland last year. The team qualified with a perfect record and is in Group D with Holland, Italy, and Ireland. Their first match is against Italy on May 7 in Burgas. The squad includes players from various Premier League clubs, with notable mentions like Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo from Chelsea, and first-time call-ups like Stephy Mavididi from Arsenal. Key players like Trent Arnold and Herbie Kane from Liverpool have been recalled. England's other matches are scheduled against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City is interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht talent Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the best from Anderlecht's youth academy. He has also caught the eye of Arsenal and Barcelona, though he previously turned down Barcelona's La Masia to focus on his studies. Manchester City has discussed a compensation package with Anderlecht's chairman to secure Patoulidis, as part of Manuel Pellegrini's strategy to invest in future talent.

A 33-year-old transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found dead in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, London, at the end of March. She had been strangled and beaten, with injuries to her head and neck. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been released on bail. The police are seeking information from anyone who had contact with her before her death. Santillan, originally from Mexico, worked in London, Paris, and Miami. The investigation is ongoing, with police urging public assistance.

Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle show to confront her friend Jamie, who lives with her and her partner, also named Jamie, about stealing £207 intended for a gravestone for her baby Daniel James. Initially, Jamie denied the theft, but a lie detector test on the show confirmed he was lying. Jamie had sent a message confessing to the theft but blamed his girlfriend Carol. Dawn was devastated by the betrayal, feeling it was a cruel response to her gesture of kindness.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis on Wednesday, primarily women and children, with some ill or elderly individuals. The release was coordinated with the help of Arab tribal leaders. The freed Yazidis were received by the Peshmerga and taken to Irbil, the Kurdish regional capital. The number of released Yazidis was reported as 217 by one official and 228 by another. ISIS has previously released other Yazidis, mainly children and the elderly, since their attacks last year. The Yazidis, a minority group of Kurdish descent with a pre-Islamic religion, have faced severe persecution, including extraordinary cruelty from ISIS, particularly after the conquest of Sinjar which led to a humanitarian crisis. The international response included airdrops, rescues, and airstrikes by the U.S. and other nations starting in August. Approximately 500,000 Yazidis live in northern Iraq.

Harry Kane, a Tottenham and England striker, has had an exceptional season, scoring notable goals including his 20th Premier League goal against Newcastle. He is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. A new animation by Copa90 features his best goals and celebrations, using still photographs to create an animated effect. This video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', was released before the awards ceremony where he competes against players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers continuing as Liverpool's manager despite a trophyless season and a probable finish outside the top four. Carragher believes Rodgers should not be judged solely on one game and that the new players need time to settle. Liverpool is currently seven points behind fourth-placed Manchester City but has a game in hand. Carragher suggests that Rodgers needs to make the right signings to improve the team's chances next season. Additionally, Carragher was honored with a Beacon Award for his community work in Merseyside, where he has been involved in coaching in underprivileged areas through his 23 Foundation.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport after it was flagged as a security risk during an X-ray scan. Despite the toy being harmless and brightly colored, security performed a pat-down on James and took the toy. His father, Phil Hayward, found the situation 'ludicrous' but had to leave the toy due to time constraints to catch their flight to Lanzarote. Upon returning, James was bought a replacement toy gun. East Midlands Airport apologized but justified their actions by stating that no items resembling prohibited items are allowed through security, as per government regulations.

A man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, named Rich, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He listed specific requirements for his ideal partner, including being a non-drinker, non-smoker, fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good with household tasks, a good cook, and skilled in bed. He offered accommodation, potential company car, phone, laptop, and gym membership as incentives. Rich described himself as 31 years old, athletic, heavily tattooed, financially successful, and enjoying outdoor activities. He emphasized his willingness to spend money on his partner and promised to consider all reasonable offers.

Greg Dyke, the Football Association chairman, is pushing for changes to increase the number of home-grown players in Premier League club squads from eight to twelve. His proposal redefines 'home-grown' to mean players trained in England for three years before turning 18. Despite opposition from the Premier League, Dyke has received support from five former England managers: Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren. They argue that rejecting these changes could hinder England's football progress and chances of winning the World Cup. They highlight the decreasing number of English players in the Premier League and stress the need for more opportunities for young English talents like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane.

In the latest episode of the show, Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, has given birth to a baby girl. Ross Poldark, portrayed by Aidan Turner, shows his affection for his new daughter and his wife, affirming his love for Demelza. The episode quickly transitions from Demelza being eight months pregnant to her giving birth, which has been noted by fans for its rapid timeline. This rapid progression of pregnancy is a recurring theme in the show, as seen with another character, Elizabeth, in previous episodes. Fans have humorously commented on the show's fast-paced depiction of pregnancies on social media.

Leicester City, managed by Nigel Pearson, is currently three points from safety in the Premier League after two consecutive wins, including a 3-2 victory over West Brom where Jamie Vardy scored a crucial injury-time goal. Despite being at the bottom of the table, Pearson is urging his team to focus on their own performance rather than their relegation rivals as they prepare to host Swansea. He emphasizes maintaining focus on their own games to control their destiny in the relegation battle, warning against over-optimism and distractions from other teams' results.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a record for the longest mammal migration, traveling nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. The migration suggests Varvara might be from the eastern gray whale population rather than the endangered western population, as she visited three major eastern breeding areas. This finding could impact the understanding of gray whale populations, suggesting some western gray whales might actually be eastern grays. The study was led by Bruce Mate from Oregon State University.

A sudden geological event on Hokkaido Island's east coast near Rausu resulted in 1,000-1,640ft of seabed rising 30-50ft above sea level overnight, creating a new stretch of land. This was caused by a landslide triggered by melting ice and snow, not related to recent earthquakes. The landmass, measuring about 100ft wide, appeared without any noticeable tremors or sounds, surprising local residents. The event is not expected to expand further. Marine life like seaweed and sea urchins are still attached to the newly exposed land.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors of leaving Paris Saint-Germain, expressing his love for the club, the city, and his teammates. Despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc over being dropped for a Champions League game, Van der Wiel is content at PSG and wishes to extend his contract. However, the club's interest in signing Dani Alves might affect his future at the club.

Carlos Tevez, currently with Juventus, has expressed his desire to leave the club this summer to return to Boca Juniors in Argentina. His contract with Juventus, which runs until 2016, needs to be terminated for the move to proceed. Boca Juniors are close to finalizing the deal, with their president confirming the negotiations. Tevez, who started his career at Boca Juniors, has been a key player for Juventus, scoring 17 goals this season. Juventus has accepted his wish to leave and is looking for replacements. His international manager, Tata Martino, supports Tevez's decision, stating it won't affect his Argentina career.

During a Champions League match at the Allianz Arena, Bayern Munich defeated Porto 6-1, advancing to the semi-finals. Bayern's manager, Pep Guardiola, tore his trousers during the match, exposing his underwear, which he humorously commented on needing to replace. Goals were scored by Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and Robert Lewandowski (who scored twice). Despite Porto's initial two-goal lead from the first leg, Bayern's performance was dominant, showcasing their superiority.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, Brisbane. Three vehicles were involved in the collision. A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy with serious injuries were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital. A 27-year-old woman and a six-year-old girl were also airlifted due to their injuries. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries. One person was trapped and freed by Queensland Fire and Rescue. The highway was closed with diversions in place south of Fernvale.

This weekend, Arsenal will host Chelsea in a crucial Premier League match. Arsenal's Mesut Ozil, who recently received a new Apple Watch, is excited for the game, comparing his watch to Michael Knight's from "Knight Rider." Arsenal trails Chelsea by 10 points with six games left. Jack Wilshere, who has returned from a five-month injury, was on the bench for Arsenal's FA Cup semi-final win. Ray Parlour believes Wilshere's fitness is key to his potential as a future star for Arsenal, drawing comparisons to the injury-plagued Abou Diaby.

Mark Clattenburg will referee the Manchester derby at Old Trafford. Despite sending off three players from Manchester United and Manchester City this season, including City captain Vincent Kompany during an international match, he has only issued two red cards in the Premier League, both to United players: Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw. Clattenburg has faced accusations of bias towards United but is considered one of the Premier League's top referees. The match is significant as it could determine the second place behind Chelsea, with United currently ahead of City by one point after recent results. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck, Jake Collin, and Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Bob Katter, a federal MP, accused the Queensland Government of treating embattled MP Billy Gordon as a 'little black puppet on a string', suggesting they expected him to resign after accusations of domestic violence and revealing his criminal past. Gordon, who left the Queensland Labor Party, decided to stay in parliament as an independent, causing political instability due to the government's slim majority. Katter, of Lebanese descent, defended his statement by relating it to his own experiences with racism, and criticized the government for racial bias in their expectations of Gordon's resignation. The statement received backlash on social media for its terminology.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, uses dance videos to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and judgment, she aims to show that people with disabilities are not fundamentally different. Her videos, including one to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," seek to entertain and encourage viewers to look beyond disabilities. Dayna has also started motivational speaking at local schools, emphasizing her normalcy and capabilities despite her condition.

Orlando City, an MLS team, has shown interest in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who has struggled during his loan at Real Madrid. Hernandez, a Mexico international, would be a significant commercial asset for Orlando due to their large Latin-American fanbase. The club, coached by Adrian Heath and captained by Kaka, made inquiries about Hernandez last week. Despite interest from eight European clubs including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan, Hernandez could join Orlando. Manchester United is open to selling him for around £8million. Additionally, Manchester United has offered a revised contract to their young prospect Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord after rejecting United's initial offer.

A group of at least three individuals set a white Dodge Charger on fire at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles around 12:15am on Saturday after an argument with the driver. The suspects attempted to carjack the driver, who escaped, leading them to douse the car with gasoline and ignite it while two passengers were inside. No one was injured, but the car was destroyed. The incident is being investigated as arson by the Los Angeles County Fire Department, with the suspects still at large. Surveillance video is part of the ongoing investigation.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, surrendered his state license after admitting to accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients. He agreed not to seek reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite these actions, he received high patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com. Manuel must prove the circumstances leading to his license revocation no longer exist before practicing again. His practice was located at a residential address in Lamoni.

The U.S. has lodged a complaint with Russia after a Russian SU-27 Flanker intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in international airspace. The U.S. described the interception as "unsafe and unprofessional" due to the Russian jet's aggressive maneuvers and high speed. Russia claimed the U.S. plane was flying towards their border with its transponder off, which the U.S. denied. This incident follows a similar event a year prior over the Sea of Okhotsk. Diplomatic channels will be used to address the issue.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in the parking lot of the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City, just before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle was secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains, but was taken by breaking the car's rear window, using a rope to pull the case out. The theft occurred overnight on March 27, and besides the rifle, the agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools were also stolen. Some of the agent's belongings were later found at a nearby Residence Inn, but the rifle remains missing. The hotel lacks surveillance cameras, and the rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer. The Secret Service was informed, but it's unclear if this affected security measures for Obama's visit.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbor Terrence Freebody in July 2012 in Red Hill, Canberra, by stomping on his head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen assessed Costa and concluded that his mental state was compromised by dementia and alcohol abuse, leading to confusion at the time of the crime. Mullen believes Costa's fluctuating mood during the incident and the trail of faeces from the crime scene to where he was found suggest his confused state. The prosecution suggested Costa might have feigned memory loss, but Mullen disagreed, stating it was likely Costa had been suffering from dementia for some time. The case hinges on proving Costa's mental instability at the time of the attack, which could result in a not guilty verdict.

In a 1-0 win against Burnley, Everton's Ross Barkley took and missed a 10th-minute penalty, despite Leighton Baines, who has a strong record from the spot, being available. Manager Roberto Martinez supported Barkley's decision, noting that multiple players could take penalties based on their confidence at the moment. Barkley's miss was saved by Burnley's Tom Heaton, but Everton still won thanks to a goal by Kevin Mirallas in the 29th minute.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the Holland America Line's ms Ryndam cruise ship in San Juan, Puerto Rico, in what appears to be a murder-suicide. The incident was discovered at 11:30 a.m. on Thursday by the cleaning staff. The cabin was secured, and authorities, including the FBI, were notified and are investigating. The ship had departed from Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has successfully led Curacao to advance in the 2018 World Cup qualification by defeating Montserrat 4-3 on aggregate. Curacao drew 2-2 in the second leg after winning the first leg 2-1. A crucial goal by substitute Charlton Vicento in the 87th minute secured their progression. Curacao will next face Cuba on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, with Curacaoan heritage, previously reached the World Cup semi-finals in 1998 as a player and in 2014 as an assistant coach.

Esteban Cambiasso, a decorated footballer with numerous trophies from his career at clubs like Inter Milan, Real Madrid, and River Plate, views keeping Leicester City in the Premier League as equivalent to winning a trophy. Leicester City is currently at the bottom of the Premier League table, seven points from safety with only eight games left. Despite the dire situation, Cambiasso remains optimistic about avoiding relegation, emphasizing the team's chances and his commitment to the challenge. He signed a one-year deal with Leicester in the summer and is happy in England, considering extending his stay beyond the current season.

Gemma, a 23-year-old mother of two young children, faces the possibility of being banned from seeing her children by her mother, Debbie, due to her ongoing issues with drinking, partying, and drug use, specifically MKat. Gemma handed over her children to Debbie when they were four months old, and Debbie has been their primary caregiver since, fearing social services might take them otherwise. Debbie accuses Gemma of stealing, including an iPad from one of the children, to support her lifestyle, though Gemma denies stealing the iPad but admits to past thefts from her mother. Debbie, feeling overwhelmed and betrayed, is considering preventing Gemma from seeing the children due to her irresponsible behavior and lack of care for them.

During a match at Stamford Bridge, Chelsea's Eden Hazard scored the opening goal against Manchester United, making it 1-0. The goal came after a controversial play where Chelsea captain John Terry made a strong challenge from behind on Manchester United's Radamel Falcao, causing him to fall. Cesc Fabregas then picked up the loose ball, passed it to Oscar, who back-heeled it to Hazard for the goal. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness all agreed during halftime that Terry's challenge on Falcao was a foul and the play should have been stopped.

Hillary Scott's tour bus from Lady Antebellum caught fire on a Texas freeway. Everyone on board, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, was safely evacuated. The fire started after a rear tire blew out, and it destroyed everything in the bus's back lounge except Scott's Bible. The incident was captured on video by Michael Barnett. The band's other members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus. Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman from Dundee University is developing space lasers to convert sunlight into energy for heating homes. These lasers, less powerful than those in science fiction, use satellites with mirrors to capture sunlight, converting it into laser light which is then transmitted back to Earth. This could make solar power viable in less sunny regions like Scotland and provide instant power in disaster areas. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, with plans to continue in Portugal. Unlike weaponized lasers, these are safe, not capable of harming even small creatures. Separately, Tokyo researchers propose using lasers on the ISS to clear space debris, targeting small objects to burn them up in Earth's atmosphere. Dr. Quarterman notes potential concerns about control of these satellites.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a fanatical obsession with young girls, has escaped from a psychiatric unit in Hook, Hampshire, where he was detained under the Mental Health Act. He was last seen leaving the hospital at 6.15pm on Tuesday. Munden, who has learning difficulties and is autistic, was convicted of sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus and has a history of possessing indecent images of children. He is described as 5ft 8ins tall, of heavy build, with dark hair, and may have shaved his beard. Authorities are urgently searching for him due to his dangerous nature and mental health issues.

Donald Sterling's racist remarks led to him losing his NBA team. Subsequently, V. Stiviano, his former companion, was ordered by a Los Angeles judge to repay over $2.6 million in gifts to Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, who sued Stiviano for targeting wealthy older men. Stiviano received luxury items like cars and a duplex from Donald Sterling, which she claimed were legitimate gifts. The court decision was celebrated by Shelly Sterling's lawyer as a victory for the family. Additionally, Sterling's downfall was triggered by a leaked audio where he made racist comments to Stiviano, leading to his ban from the NBA, a $2.5 million fine, and the loss of his franchise ownership.

Thierry Henry, a former Arsenal player, has criticized the club's transfer strategy and suggested they need to sign four key players to compete for the Premier League title: a goalkeeper, a centre back, a defensive midfielder, and a top-quality striker. He made these comments after Arsenal's goalless draw with Chelsea, specifically questioning whether Olivier Giroud, who has scored 14 league goals this season, can lead Arsenal to the title. Henry used Chelsea's successful signings like Courtois, Matic, Fabregas, and Costa as examples of the caliber of players Arsenal should aim for. Arsenal is currently third in the league, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand.

A young woman, a victim of Maurice Van Ryn, the Bega Cheese boss, spoke in court about the severe impact of his abuse on her life. Van Ryn, a wealthy NSW businessman, pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who kept the abuse secret for years, only spoke out after learning Van Ryn was caught. She expressed fears about her future relationships, confusion over why she was targeted, and the impact on her mental health, including depression and suicide attempts. Van Ryn remained calm and did not look at her during her testimony. The hearing is ongoing.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is recovering from a serious knee injury that sidelined him since March 2014. He recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under-21 team against Reading, marking his second full game in a week. Gnabry feels he is improving and is optimistic about his return to play, expressing that he is over his injury concerns.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, died after falling 70ft from a cliff while trying to avoid paying a taxi fare. After a night out in Cardiff, he and his friends didn't have enough money for the taxi ride to Penarth. Phillips ran from the taxi, leading to him jumping over a fence in the dark and falling to his death. His body was found the next day by a dog walker at the base of the cliff. The coroner concluded it was an accidental death, noting Phillips was likely disoriented and unaware of the danger. Phillips was from Reading, had studied at the University of Birmingham, and was working for Pretty Green at the time of his death.

Last summer, thousands of holidaymakers affected by passport delays did not receive compensation, despite the passport agency making a £42 million profit. Managers received bonuses up to £3,500. Only 2,191 out of thousands of compensation claims were approved, totaling £203,066, with an average payout of £92.68. The backlog was due to 3.6 million applications, with over half a million stuck by mid-June. Ministers refused a blanket refund, fearing it would set a precedent. Specific cases like Mathew Bean and Hayley Kirkham, who lost £1,500 on a trip due to delayed passports, were among those not compensated.

A 1930s timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, is for sale, untouched for over 80 years. It features original elements like stained-glass windows, oil-fired heating, and retro food jars. The semi-detached property includes a wood-panelled hallway, original bathroom with mint green and black decor, and kitchen with vintage cupboards. It has three bedrooms, double glazing, and retains original items like Cadbury’s Marvel dried milk. Priced between £200,000 and £250,000, it's ideal for antique enthusiasts but might deter developers due to renovation costs. The auction is set for April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started his NFL career as a backup to Alex Smith. He became the starting quarterback for the San Francisco 49ers in 2012 after Smith's concussion. Kaepernick led the team to the Super Bowl that year, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
"Soul Food" is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and was released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and lived there before moving to Texas and then San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to NY 495 in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan via the Lincoln Tunnel.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language television network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone, East London, and Colchester, Essex, attended Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon, leading to the formation of Blur. Blur's debut album "Leisure" was released in 1991 with mixed reviews, while their self-titled album in 2001 was a worldwide success, influenced by various music genres. Albarn's solo debut, "Everyday Robots," was released on 28 April 2014, co-produced by Richard Russell, featuring collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and others, and included samples from Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, also known locally as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. It hosts many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their debut EP, *Broken*, released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

The 2007 film "Shooter" features Bob Lee Swagger, played by Mark Wahlberg, a Force Recon veteran who is framed for murder by a rogue private military company. The TV series "Shooter" stars Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman in exile, who returns to action upon discovering a conspiracy to assassinate the president.
"House," also known as "House, M.D.," is an American medical drama that aired on Fox for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, orchestrated by members of his group. He was also convicted for the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. Following his charges, commercial recordings of songs he wrote and performed were released.

Sean Justin Penn, born on August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He started his career with a TV appearance in 1974 and made his film debut in 1981. Penn gained critical acclaim for roles in crime dramas during the 1980s and 1990s. He received his first Academy Award nomination for "Dead Man Walking" in 1995, and won Best Actor Oscars for "Mystic River" in 2003 and "Milk" in 2008. He also received nominations for "Sweet and Lowdown" in 1999 and "I Am Sam" in 2001.

Sir Donald Bradman, known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer considered the greatest batsman ever. After retiring, he remained influential in cricket for 30 years as an administrator, selector, and writer.

L.A. Reid has held significant executive positions in the music industry, including Chairman and CEO of Epic Records, President and CEO of Arista Records, and Chairman and CEO of Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is best known as the drummer for Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000, 2007-2011) and Audioslave (2001-2007). He began his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in 1991 with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha. As of 2016, he is part of Prophets of Rage, alongside Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Note: The passage also mentions a different band named Rage, a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner, which is unrelated to Wilk's involvement.

The Millers was a multi-camera TV series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, spanning 34 episodes over two seasons. CBS canceled the show on November 14, 2014, during its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (1933-2006) was the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995, a Democrat who gained national attention as state treasurer and for her keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. She was defeated by George W. Bush in 1994. She was the second female governor of Texas, known for her feminism and witty remarks. Ann Richards (1935-1982) was a separate individual, an American jazz singer and wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell released an EP titled "A Reminder" independently in 2011.

The passage discusses the 1979 American drama film "Boardwalk," which was written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Additionally, it provides biographical details about Janet Leigh, noting her birth name (Jeanette Helen Morrison), her lifespan (1927-2004), her career as an actress, singer, dancer, and author, and mentions that she wrote four books, including two novels, between 1984 and 2002.

Simón Bolívar, known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan leader who played a key role in the independence of Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama from Spanish rule. He lived from 1783 to 1830.
The Bermuda Triangle, or Devil's Triangle, is a region in the western North Atlantic Ocean known for the mysterious disappearances of numerous aircraft and ships.

Colin Kaepernick started his NFL career as a backup to Alex Smith but became the San Francisco 49ers' starting quarterback in 2012 after Smith's concussion. He led the 49ers to the Super Bowl that year, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens. In his first full season as a starter in 2013, he took the 49ers to the NFC Championship, where they were defeated by the Seattle Seahawks.
"Marnie" is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a form of marketing communication that uses nonpersonal, openly sponsored messages to promote products, services, or ideas. Unlike personal selling, it is not directed at specific individuals. It is disseminated through various media, including traditional forms like newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, outdoor advertising, and direct mail, as well as modern forms like search results, blogs, websites, and text messages.
**Summary:** "Private Lives" is a 1930 comedy of manners play by Noël Coward and was adapted into a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician who served as Prime Minister of the UK from January 10, 1957, to October 19, 1963. He was born on February 10, 1894, and died on December 29, 1986.

Aristotle (384-322 BC) was a Greek philosopher and scientist from Stagira, Chalkidice. He studied at Plato's Academy in Athens from age 17 or 18 until 37. After Plato's death, Aristotle tutored Alexander the Great from 343 BC at the request of Philip II of Macedon.

David Mordechai Packouz, born on February 16, 1982, is an American who was previously an arms dealer. He is also known for his work as a musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. Packouz invented the BeatBuddy, a guitar pedal drum machine, and is the CEO of Singular Sound, a music technology company.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons. He was the first overall pick in the 1979 NBA draft after winning championships in high school and college. Johnson won a championship and Finals MVP in his rookie year, and four more championships in the 1980s. He retired twice, returning briefly in 1996 at age 36. Beyond basketball, he was recognized as an influential black businessman by Ebony magazine in 2009 and has various business interests, including being a part-owner of the Lakers.

Tenacious D, formed in 1994 in Los Angeles, consists of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They have released three albums: "Tenacious D" (2001), "The Pick of Destiny" (2006), and "Rize of the Fenix" (2012). The band gained fame in 1997 through their TV series and by supporting major rock acts.

James VI and I was King of Scotland from 1567 and King of England and Ireland from 1603 until his death in 1625. He ruled both countries in personal union, with each having its own parliament, judiciary, and laws. James advocated for a single parliament for both nations, achieving more success in Scotland than in England, where he faced challenges like the Gunpowder Plot and conflicts with Parliament.

**Summary:**

- **Big Brother 2017** (also known as Big Brother 18) is the 18th series of the British reality TV show, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley.
- Marcus Bentley, born on October 4, 1967, is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist, famous for narrating Big Brother UK since 2000.
- Bentley worked with Channel 4 until 2011, then continued with Big Brother on Channel 5.

Sheikh Ali Salman emphasized the need for meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain, requiring concrete solutions from the government and direct involvement from the royal family, particularly Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, who is seen as a reformist. Christopher Hogwood, a prominent figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned for later. Hogwood founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, leading it for 30 years across six continents and producing over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Notable recordings include a 1980 version of Handel's Messiah. He studied at Cambridge University and held various prestigious positions, including roles with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields, King's Lynn Festival, and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. He was also an academic at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell Universities. Colleagues and peers praised his generosity, academic prowess, and his significant contributions to historically informed music performance.

- In the year ending March, there were 57 recorded homicides in Scotland, a decrease of 5 from the previous year, marking the lowest since 1976 and half the number from nine years ago.
- As of March 31, 2016, only one homicide from 2015-16 remained unresolved.
- Sharp instruments, predominantly knives (26 out of 29 cases), were the most common method, accounting for 51% of homicides.
- 31% of accused were under the influence of alcohol or drugs.
- Justice Secretary Michael Matheson emphasized the need for continued efforts in education and enforcement to reduce violent crime, focusing on community support and addressing alcohol misuse.
- Scottish Labour's Claire Baker cautioned against over-optimism due to past revisions in figures and highlighted a rise in sexual crimes and violent crimes like attempted murder and serious assault by 27%.

Bournemouth (referred to as The Cherries) lost 2-1 to Sunderland in a Premier League match, marking Sunderland's first win of the season. Dan Gosling scored Bournemouth's first goal in three games, giving them the lead. However, Sunderland came back with goals from Victor Anichebe and a penalty by Jermain Defoe. Despite having numerous chances and playing against 10 men after Steven Pienaar's red card, Bournemouth couldn't equalize. Manager Eddie Howe expressed frustration over the team's inability to convert chances, noting they had enough opportunities to win three games. He emphasized the importance of moving forward from this defeat.

Mr. Abbott stated that the only way to prevent deaths at sea is to "stop the boats," referring to Australia's policy of detaining migrants who arrive by boat and processing them offshore for resettlement elsewhere. The New York Times criticized this policy as "brutal," "inhumane," and legally questionable, contrasting it with Australia's history of welcoming refugees. Abbott suggested European leaders should consider similar policies. He commented on the tragic death of Alan Kurdi, reinforcing his stance on stopping boats to prevent drownings. Additionally, Abbott controversially compared IS to the Nazis, suggesting IS was worse due to their lack of shame in their evil acts, which drew criticism from Australian Jewish groups for the comparison's inappropriateness. Abbott later clarified he wasn't ranking evils but stood by his comments.

Washington accused Russia and the Syrian government of escalating attacks on civilians in Aleppo, leading the US to suspend bilateral talks with Russia unless the bombing ceased. Russia expressed regret over the US decision, claiming the US was shifting blame for the failed truce. Since the ceasefire ended, Aleppo has faced intense aerial attacks, with a key hospital in the rebel-held east being struck multiple times. Over 250,000 people are trapped in eastern Aleppo, and many have died in the government's offensive to control the city. The US criticized Russia for not adhering to ceasefire agreements and for targeting infrastructure and blocking aid. Russia denied involvement in an attack on a humanitarian convoy, attributing it to ground fire. The US has withdrawn personnel meant for a joint implementation center with Russia, but both countries will continue discussions on counter-terrorism to prevent conflicts.

The Policy Exchange report, supported by Downing Street, suggests selling high-value vacant social homes to raise £4.5bn annually, which could fund the construction of 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes. This could be the largest social housing program since the 1970s, potentially reducing the social housing waiting list by 500,000 from the current 1.8 million. Critics, including Labour, argue this would displace low-income families from expensive areas, leading to community segregation. The report defines expensive social housing as properties worth more than the regional average, accounting for 21.8% of the UK's social housing stock, or 816,000 properties, with London holding over £70bn worth. Annually, 3.5% of social housing becomes vacant, allowing for the sale of 28,500 properties, raising £5.5bn before debt repayment. Public opinion, according to the report, supports not giving council houses worth more than local averages to tenants. However, opposition fears this could lead to the creation of new ghettos and the erosion of mixed communities.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died at his home in Swansea amidst a measles epidemic with 942 cases. The cause of his death is uncertain, with an inquest pending further tests. He had been treated for asthma and later developed a rash, visiting a GP before being found dead. Laboratory tests confirmed he had measles, but the exact cause of death remains under investigation. His family, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, are unaware of how he contracted the disease.

Vincent Hudson, 54, from Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical sexual offence against a boy under 16, which occurred in 2001. He is scheduled to appear at North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

In a National League match, Guiseley took an early lead against Gateshead with a goal from Jake Lawlor in the 15th minute. Bristol Sport Ltd plans to replace two stands at their football club to increase capacity, as an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which is delayed. The project was approved by Bristol City Council in November. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown announced at a shareholder meeting that they would start work in May if there is no judicial review by March, following the signing of a section 106 agreement.

Cuadrilla suspended shale gas drilling (fracking) operations after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months, to analyze data from the British Geological Survey (BGS). The tremor was similar to one on April 1st near Poulton-le-Fylde. Fracking involves fracturing shale rocks to release gas. Cuadrilla's CEO emphasized their responsibility, halting operations for consultation expected to last weeks. The process is controversial due to environmental concerns, but UK support has been suggested with proper regulation. The BGS monitors fracking and noted that fluid injection can cause earthquakes. The latest tremor was felt in Poulton-Le-Fylde, with its epicenter near the Preese Hall site at a depth of about 2km, similar to the previous event.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old busker from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud for playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015, suggesting he was collecting money for the campaign. He was acquitted of two other fraud charges. Carpenter claimed he was not collecting funds for the charity but was simply busking, with the banner as a tribute to the victims. He had previously performed for the charity with permission to display the banner, but not to collect funds. His sentencing is scheduled for January.

Managers Mick McCarthy and Ian Holloway commented on the game, with McCarthy praising his team's performance and Holloway criticizing his team's defensive lapse and mental toughness.

Key players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams were instrumental, with the front row and five making over 70 tackles.
